Since you didn’t give us much to go on - no encoder type or how it’s connected and what software you are using - I have to guess the model and guess it is a quad encoder. You have to use the WPILib quad encoder software if connecting to the roboRIO or connect it correctly to your motor controller. There are two outputs A and B that need two roboRIO DIO ports if that’s where you want to connect it otherwise follow your motor controller instructions.

[I’m guessing you have THIS and it would have been nice if you had told us .]

","post_number":4,"post_type":1,"posts_count":7,"updated_at":"2025-03-11T02:35:34.933Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":3,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":130,"readers_count":129,"score":31.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":495066,"topic_slug":"encoder","display_username":"SLAB-Mr.Thomas","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.ia.omron.com/product/item/2450/","internal":false,"reflection":false,"clicks":20}],"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":59989,"username":"Neno","name":"Matheus Henrique de Faria Pereira ","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/n/a88e4f/{size}.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":24594,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/encoder/495066/4","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3554068,"name":"Diego dos Santos Amaral ","username":"Feldix","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/f/4af34b/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-11T15:44:09.642Z","cooked":"

Sorry for the lack of information. I’m also on the team and I’ll try to be more specific. Yes, it is this encoder model that we are using. Instead of plugging into the DIO ports, we used a breakout board to directly connect the Talon SRX’s data port. For some reason it doesn’t read negative rotations, I checked it in the phoenix tuner as well. I thought it might be a wrong electrical connection of signals A and B, but I don’t know if that seems to be the case. When I tested it before with a strip terminal to connect the data port with the encoder, it read both directions. We are using python, here is the code:

from wpilib import TimedRobot, XboxController, SmartDashboard
from phoenix5 import WPI_TalonSRX, ControlMode, NeutralMode, FeedbackDevice
from wpilib.shuffleboard import Shuffleboard

class Robot(TimedRobot):
    def robotInit(self):
        #configura qual talon para teste
        self.tower_motor = WPI_TalonSRX(4) 

        # Configura o encoder incremental como sensor de feedback
        self.tower_motor.configSelectedFeedbackSensor(FeedbackDevice.QuadEncoder, 0, 10)


        self.controller = XboxController(0)  # Controle de Xbox
                            

        # Definir o modo Brake para evitar quedas bruscas
        self.tower_motor.setNeutralMode(NeutralMode.Brake)

        # garante que se o motor é positivo, o encoder também é positivo
        self.tower_motor.setSensorPhase(True)

    def teleopPeriodic(self):

        """Controla a torre baseado nos botões"""

        if self.controller.getRawButton(2):  # Botão 3 -> Subir manualmente
            self.tower_motor.set(ControlMode.PercentOutput, 1.0)

        elif self.controller.getRawButton(3):  # Botão 2 -> Descer manualmente
            self.tower_motor.set(ControlMode.PercentOutput, -1.0)



    def robotPeriodic(self):

        if self.controller.getRawButton(3): # **Reseta o encoder caso o botão 3 seja pressionado**
           self.tower_motor.setSelectedSensorPosition(0, 0, 10)

        # **Ler posição do encoder**
        self.encoder_position = self.tower_motor.getSelectedSensorPosition(0)

        # **Enviar valor do encoder para a Dashboard**
        SmartDashboard.putNumber("Encoder Position (ticks)", self.encoder_position)

The more precisely you can describe what the inputs are and what the outputs are, the better people are able to help.

For example when you say it doesn’t read negative rotations, do you meant that if you rotate it forward and then rotate it backward, the reported position will increase while rotating forward and stops changing when you rotate it backward? Or do you mean it will increase when rotating it forward and decrease when rotating backward, but never reads below 0 even when continuing to rotate it backwards. Or do you mean when you rotate it forward it reads more negative and when you rotate it backward it reads positive? Or something else?

Okay, sorry again. When we rotate the engine forward, it increments the value. When we rotate backwards, it remains at the same value it was when it stopped. So if I rotated forward until I stopped at position 2000, and suddenly I started rotating in reverse, it stays at 2000. If I rotate forward again, it increases the value again. I took signal A from the encoder (black wire), signal B (white wire), 5v (brown wire) and gnd (blue wire) and placed them in their respective positions on the breakout board. Then I took a data cable and plugged it into the talon srx’s data port
